linkTarget.anchoringText: The Permian Delaware basin is one of the most prolific unconventional oil and gas basins in the US. Fig.1 –shows Eddy and Lea Counties of the Delaware basin, as the leading oil producing counties in the Permian.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: RRC Reported Estimated Cumulative Crude Oil Production by County (Jan 2004-Jul 2015) – Courtesy NGI

formatted-caption.caption-text: RRC Reported Estimated Cumulative Crude Oil Production by County (Jan 2004-Jul 2015) – Courtesy NGI

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Delaware Basin is a multi-stacked play prospect; that contains several productive zones (see Fig.2&3 below). Hydrocarbon producing zone thickness as high as 1800 feet are common in the basin; comparing this to the Bakken Shale highs of 120 feet in thickness, and Eagle Ford Shale formations of 300 feet thick (NGI’Shale Daily, 2016); the Delaware basin is no doubt a world class oil and gas basin.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Delaware Basin Wolfcamp dwarfed Williston Basin Bakken & Three Forks Midland Basin Wolfcamp/Cline Delaware Basin Wolfcamp Williston Basin Bakken & Three Forks

formatted-caption.caption-text: Delaware Basin Wolfcamp dwarfed Williston Basin Bakken & Three Forks Midland Basin Wolfcamp/Cline Delaware Basin Wolfcamp Williston Basin Bakken & Three Forks

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Delaware Basin is a multi-stacked play prospect; that contains several productive zones (see Fig.2&3 below). Hydrocarbon producing zone thickness as high as 1800 feet are common in the basin; comparing this to the Bakken Shale highs of 120 feet in thickness, and Eagle Ford Shale formations of 300 feet thick (NGI’Shale Daily, 2016); the Delaware basin is no doubt a world class oil and gas basin.
This paper groups all major factors to consider in artificial lift elimination and selection into four main categories for better understanding (see Fig. 4):

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Artificial Lift Elimination and Selection Consideration Categories

formatted-caption.caption-text: Artificial Lift Elimination and Selection Consideration Categories

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the Delaware basin, the geological depositional environment, reservoir and fluid properties, not only varies by formation with depth (Fig.2); strong regional variation is observed with distance in the same formation. See Fig. 5 below, it highlighted the GOR variation in the basin. This provided additional layer of complexity to defining artificial lift strategy to maximize the asset value. Definitely, this is the main reason why – one artificial lift type strategy, is not always an effective strategy.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: 180 Day GOR’s Plot - 2nd Bone Spring Sand Horizontal Wells in Eddy County, Delaware Basin

formatted-caption.caption-text: 180 Day GOR’s Plot - 2nd Bone Spring Sand Horizontal Wells in Eddy County, Delaware Basin

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 6, 7 & 8 show historical production trends and data for Well 1, Well 2 and Well 3. The initial ESP installation equipped with downhole sensor provided valuable Pump Intake Pressure (PIP) data. A plot of ESP PIP versus GOR provided a comprehensive understanding of the behavior of the phases at different PIP.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Well 1 – Production trend and GOR vs PiP Plot

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 9 & 10 shows the model and sensitivity analysis result. Gas Lift was able to generate a sandface BHFP of 286psi, even at water cut as high as 85%. Also, tubing head pressure is the biggest factor in Gas Lift performance. The lowest tubing pressure of 50psi generated the lowest BHFP on the sensitivity plot in Fig.10.

Fig. 9 & 10 shows the model and sensitivity analysis result. Gas Lift was able to generate a sandface BHFP of 286psi, even at water cut as high as 85%. Also, tubing head pressure is the biggest factor in Gas Lift performance. The lowest tubing pressure of 50psi generated the lowest BHFP on the sensitivity plot in Fig.10.

As described in previous sections of this paper, maximum reservoir drawdown does not necessarily equate to maximum oil production. Free gas production increases significantly with BHFP reduction (Fig.11). This results in reduction of liquid (oil) production. This invariably affects the asset EUR.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: GOR increases as BHFP reduces (Gas Damage)

formatted-caption.caption-text: GOR increases as BHFP reduces (Gas Damage)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Current and Future Gas Lift Performance on a volatile oil shale was modeled, based on the output of a type curve similar to Fig.12.Table 3: is the output data for the Prosper nodal analysis that was performed with the Solution GOR of 2454 scf/bbl: Total – 5000scf/bbl.
